text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who entered Egypt—each man with his household entered with Jacob:
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people who were directly descended from Jacob numbered seventy. But Joseph was already in Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in time Joseph and his brothers and all that generation died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites, however, were fruitful, increased greatly, multiplied, and became extremely strong, so that the land was filled with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a new king, who did not know about Joseph, came to power over Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his people, “Look at the Israelite people, more numerous and stronger than we are!
speaker: Narrator

text: Come, let’s deal wisely with them. Otherwise they will continue to multiply, and if a war breaks out, they will ally themselves with our enemies and fight against us and leave the country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they put foremen over the Israelites to oppress them with hard labor. As a result they built Pithom and Rameses as store cities for Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the more the Egyptians oppressed them, the more they multiplied and spread. As a result the Egyptians loathed the Israelites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they made the Israelites serve rigorously.
speaker: Narrator

text: They made their lives bitter by hard service with mortar and bricks and by all kinds of service in the fields. Every kind of service the Israelites were required to give was rigorous.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Egypt said to the Hebrew midwives, one of whom was named Shiphrah and the other Puah,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you assist the Hebrew women in childbirth, observe at the delivery: If it is a son, kill him, but if it is a daughter, she may live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the midwives feared God and did not do what the king of Egypt had told them; they let the boys live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Egypt summoned the midwives and said to them, “Why have you done this and let the boys live?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The midwives said to Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women—for the Hebrew women are vigorous; they give birth before the midwife gets to them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God treated the midwives well, and the people multiplied and became very strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because the midwives feared God, he made households for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh commanded all his people, “All sons that are born you must throw into the river, but all daughters you may let live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A man from the household of Levi married a woman who was a descendant of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman became pregnant and gave birth to a son. When she saw that he was a healthy child, she hid him for three months.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when she was no longer able to hide him, she took a papyrus basket for him and sealed it with bitumen and pitch. She put the child in it and set it among the reeds along the edge of the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: His sister stationed herself at a distance to find out what would happen to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the daughter of Pharaoh came down to wash herself by the Nile, while her attendants were walking alongside the river, and she saw the basket among the reeds. She sent one of her attendants, took it,
speaker: Narrator

text: opened it, and saw the child—a boy, crying!—and she felt compassion for him and said, “This is one of the Hebrews’ children.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, “Shall I go and get a nursing woman for you from the Hebrews, so that she may nurse the child for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Yes, do so.” So the young girl went and got the child’s mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this child and nurse him for me, and I will pay your wages.” So the woman took the child and nursed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the child grew older she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, saying, “Because I drew him from the water.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, when Moses had grown up, he went out to his people and observed their hard labor, and he saw an Egyptian man attacking a Hebrew man, one of his own people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked this way and that and saw that no one was there, and then he attacked the Egyptian and concealed the body in the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he went out the next day, there were two Hebrew men fighting. So he said to the one who was in the wrong, “Why are you attacking your fellow Hebrew?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man replied, “Who made you a ruler and a judge over us? Are you planning to kill me like you killed that Egyptian?” Then Moses was afraid, thinking, “Surely what I did has become known.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh heard about this event, he sought to kill Moses. So Moses fled from Pharaoh and settled in the land of Midian, and he settled by a certain well.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now a priest of Midian had seven daughters, and they came and began to draw water and fill the troughs in order to water their father’s flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: When some shepherds came and drove them away, Moses came up and defended them and then watered their flock.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when they came home to their father Reuel, he asked, “Why have you come home so early today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said, “An Egyptian man rescued us from the shepherds, and he actually drew water for us and watered the flock!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to his daughters, “So where is he? Why in the world did you leave the man? Call him, so that he may eat a meal with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses agreed to stay with the man, and he gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she bore a son, Moses named him Gershom, for he said, “I have become a resident foreigner in a foreign land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: During that long period of time the king of Egypt died, and the Israelites groaned because of the slave labor. They cried out, and their desperate cry because of their slave labor went up to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: God heard their groaning; God remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: God saw the Israelites, and God understood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses was shepherding the flock of his father-in-law Jethro, the priest of Midian, and he led the flock to the far side of the desert and came to the mountain of God, to Horeb.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord appeared to him in a flame of fire from within a bush. He looked, and the bush was ablaze with fire, but it was not being consumed!
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses thought, “I will turn aside to see this amazing sight. Why does the bush not burn up?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord saw that he had turned aside to look, God called to him from within the bush and said, “Moses, Moses!” And Moses said, “Here I am.”
speaker: God

text: God said, “Do not approach any closer! Take your sandals off your feet, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.”
speaker: God

text: He added, “I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.” Then Moses hid his face, because he was afraid to look at God.
speaker: God

text: The Lord said, “I have surely seen the affliction of my people who are in Egypt. I have heard their cry because of their taskmasters, for I know their sorrows.
speaker: God

text: I have come down to deliver them from the hand of the Egyptians and to bring them up from that land to a land that is both good and spacious, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the region of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
speaker: God

text: And now indeed the cry of the Israelites has come to me, and I have also seen how severely the Egyptians oppress them.
speaker: God

text: So now go, and I will send you to Pharaoh to bring my people, the Israelites, out of Egypt.”
speaker: God

text: Moses said to God, “Who am I that I should go to Pharaoh, or that I should bring the Israelites out of Egypt?”
speaker: God

text: He replied, “Surely I will be with you, and this will be the sign to you that I have sent you: When you bring the people out of Egypt, you and they will serve God at this mountain.”
speaker: God

text: Moses said to God, “If I go to the Israelites and tell them, ‘The God of your fathers has sent me to you,’ and they ask me, ‘What is his name?’—what should I say to them?”
speaker: God

text: God said to Moses, “I AM that I AM.” And he said, “You must say this to the Israelites, ‘I AM has sent me to you.’”
speaker: God

text: God also said to Moses, “You must say this to the Israelites, ‘The Lord—the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob—has sent me to you. This is my name forever, and this is my memorial from generation to generation.’
speaker: God

text: “Go and bring together the elders of Israel and tell them, ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, appeared to me—the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob—saying, “I have attended carefully to you and to what has been done to you in Egypt,
speaker: God

text: and I have promised that I will bring you up out of the affliction of Egypt to the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, to a land flowing with milk and honey.”’
speaker: God

text: “The elders will listen to you, and then you and the elders of Israel must go to the king of Egypt and tell him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. So now, let us go three days’ journey into the wilderness, so that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God.’
speaker: God

text: But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go, not even under force.
speaker: God

text: So I will extend my hand and strike Egypt with all my wonders that I will do among them, and after that he will release you.
speaker: God

text: “I will grant this people favor with the Egyptians, so that when you depart you will not leave empty-handed.
speaker: God

text: Every woman will ask her neighbor and the one who happens to be staying in her house for items of silver and gold and for clothing. You will put these articles on your sons and daughters—thus you will plunder Egypt!”
speaker: God

text: Moses answered again, “And if they do not believe me or pay attention to me, but say, ‘The Lord has not appeared to you’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?” He said, “A staff.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Throw it to the ground.” So he threw it to the ground, and it became a snake, and Moses ran from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Moses, “Put out your hand and grab it by the tail”—so he put out his hand and caught it, and it became a staff in his hand—
speaker: Narrator

text: “that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also said to him, “Put your hand into your robe.” So he put his hand into his robe, and when he brought it out—there was his hand, leprous like snow!
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Put your hand back into your robe.” So he put his hand back into his robe, and when he brought it out from his robe—there it was, restored like the rest of his skin!
speaker: Narrator

text: “If they do not believe you or pay attention to the former sign, then they may believe the latter sign.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if they do not believe even these two signs or listen to you, then take some water from the Nile and pour it out on the dry ground. The water you take out of the Nile will become blood on the dry ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to the Lord, “O my Lord, I am not an eloquent man, neither in the past nor since you have spoken to your servant, for I am slow of speech and slow of tongue.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Who gave a mouth to man, or who makes a person mute or deaf or seeing or blind? Is it not I, the Lord?
speaker: Narrator

text: So now go, and I will be with your mouth and will teach you what you must say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “O my Lord, please send anyone else whom you wish to send!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord became angry with Moses, and he said, “What about your brother Aaron the Levite? I know that he can speak very well. Moreover, he is coming to meet you, and when he sees you he will be glad in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So you are to speak to him and put the words in his mouth. And as for me, I will be with your mouth and with his mouth, and I will teach you both what you must do.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will speak for you to the people, and it will be as if he were your mouth and as if you were his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will also take in your hand this staff, with which you will do the signs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went back to his father-in-law Jethro and said to him, “Let me go, so that I may return to my relatives in Egypt and see if they are still alive.” Jethro said to Moses, “Go in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses in Midian, “Go back to Egypt, because all the men who were seeking your life are dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses took his wife and sons and put them on a donkey and headed back to the land of Egypt, and Moses took the staff of God in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “When you go back to Egypt, see that you do before Pharaoh all the wonders I have put under your control. But I will harden his heart and he will not let the people go.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must say to Pharaoh, ‘This is what the Lord has said, “Israel is my son, my firstborn,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I said to you, ‘Let my son go that he may serve me,’ but since you have refused to let him go, I will surely kill your son, your firstborn!”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on the way, at a place where they stopped for the night, the Lord met Moses and sought to kill him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zipporah took a flint knife, cut off the foreskin of her son and touched it to Moses’ feet, and said, “Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord let him alone. (At that time she said, “A bridegroom of blood,” referring to the circumcision.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “Go to the wilderness to meet Moses. So he went and met him at the mountain of God and greeted him with a kiss.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord who had sent him and all the signs that he had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went and brought together all the Israelite elders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron spoke all the words that the Lord had spoken to Moses and did the signs in the sight of the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the people believed. When they heard that the Lord had attended to the Israelites and that he had seen their affliction, they bowed down close to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, has said, ‘Release my people so that they may hold a pilgrim feast to me in the wilderness.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord that I should obey him by releasing Israel? I do not know the Lord, and I will not release Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Let us go a three-day journey into the wilderness so that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God, so that he does not strike us with plague or the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why do you cause the people to refrain from their work? Return to your labor!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh was thinking, “The people of the land are now many, and you are giving them rest from their labor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day Pharaoh commanded the slave masters and foremen who were over the people:
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must no longer give straw to the people for making bricks as before. Let them go and collect straw for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must require of them the same quota of bricks that they were making before. Do not reduce it, for they are slackers. That is why they are crying, ‘Let us go sacrifice to our God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the work harder for the men so they will keep at it and pay no attention to lying words!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the slave masters of the people and their foremen went to the Israelites and said, “Thus says Pharaoh: ‘I am not giving you straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: You go get straw for yourselves wherever you can find it, because there will be no reduction at all in your workload.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people spread out through all the land of Egypt to collect stubble for straw.
speaker: Narrator

text: The slave masters were pressuring them, saying, “Complete your work for each day, just like when there was straw!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite foremen whom Pharaoh’s slave masters had set over them were beaten and were asked, “Why did you not complete your requirement for brickmaking as in the past—both yesterday and today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite foremen went and cried out to Pharaoh, “Why are you treating your servants this way?
speaker: Narrator

text: No straw is given to your servants, but we are told, ‘Make bricks!’ Your servants are even being beaten, but the fault is with your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh replied, “You are slackers! Slackers! That is why you are saying, ‘Let us go sacrifice to the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, get back to work! You will not be given straw, but you must still produce your quota of bricks!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite foremen saw that they were in trouble when they were told, “You must not reduce the daily quota of your bricks.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When they went out from Pharaoh, they encountered Moses and Aaron standing there to meet them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they said to them, “May the Lord look on you and judge, because you have made us stink in the opinion of Pharaoh and his servants, so that you have given them an excuse to kill us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses returned to the Lord, and said, “Lord, why have you caused trouble for this people? Why did you ever send me?
speaker: Narrator

text: From the time I went to speak to Pharaoh in your name, he has caused trouble for this people, and you have certainly not rescued them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh, for compelled by my strong hand he will release them, and by my strong hand he will drive them out of his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God spoke to Moses and said to him, “I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob as God Almighty, but by my name ‘the Lord’ I was not known to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also established my covenant with them to give them the land of Canaan, where they were living as resident foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have also heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians are enslaving, and I have remembered my covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, tell the Israelites, ‘I am the Lord. I will bring you out from your enslavement to the Egyptians, I will rescue you from the hard labor they impose, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with great judgments.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take you to myself for a people, and I will be your God. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from your enslavement to the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring you to the land I swore to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob—and I will give it to you as a possession. I am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told this to the Israelites, but they did not listen to him because of their discouragement and hard labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go, tell Pharaoh king of Egypt that he must release the Israelites from his land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses replied to the Lord, “If the Israelites did not listen to me, then how will Pharaoh listen to me, since I speak with difficulty?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron and gave them a charge for the Israelites and Pharaoh king of Egypt to bring the Israelites out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the heads of their fathers’ households:
The sons of Reuben, the firstborn son of Israel, were Hanoch and Pallu, Hezron and Carmi. These were the clans of Reuben.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar, and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman. These were the clans of Simeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these were the names of the sons of Levi, according to their records: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. (The length of Levi’s life was 137 years.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Gershon, by their families, were Libni and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. (The length of Kohath’s life was 133 years.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These were the clans of Levi, according to their records.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amram married his father’s sister Jochebed, and she bore him Aaron and Moses. (The length of Amram’s life was 137 years.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg, and Zikri.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron married Elisheba, the daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph. These were the Korahite clans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now Eleazar son of Aaron married one of the daughters of Putiel and she bore him Phinehas.
These were the heads of the fathers’ households of Levi according to their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was the same Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring the Israelites out of the land of Egypt by their regiments.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They were the men who were speaking to Pharaoh king of Egypt, in order to bring the Israelites out of Egypt. It was the same Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: he said to him, “I am the Lord. Tell Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I am telling you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said before the Lord, “Since I speak with difficulty, why should Pharaoh listen to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to Moses, “See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to speak everything I command you, and your brother Aaron is to tell Pharaoh that he must release the Israelites from his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and although I will multiply my signs and my wonders in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh will not listen to you. I will reach into Egypt and bring out my regiments, my people the Israelites, from the land of Egypt with great acts of judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I extend my hand over Egypt and bring the Israelites out from among them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses and Aaron did so; they did just as the Lord commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Moses was eighty years old and Aaron was eighty-three years old when they spoke to Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Do a miracle,’ and you say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh,’ it will become a snake.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh, they did so, just as the Lord had commanded them—Aaron threw down his staff before Pharaoh and his servants and it became a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh also summoned wise men and sorcerers, and the magicians of Egypt by their secret arts did the same thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each man threw down his staff, and the staffs became snakes. But Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet Pharaoh’s heart became hard, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is hard; he refuses to release the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning when he goes out to the water. Position yourself to meet him by the edge of the Nile, and take in your hand the staff that was turned into a snake.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to you to say, “Release my people, that they may serve me in the wilderness!” But until now you have not listened.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord has said: “By this you will know that I am the Lord: I am going to strike the water of the Nile with the staff that is in my hand, and it will be turned into blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fish in the Nile will die, the Nile will stink, and the Egyptians will be unable to drink water from the Nile.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Take your staff and stretch out your hand over Egypt’s waters—over their rivers, over their canals, over their ponds, and over all their reservoirs—so that it becomes blood.’ There will be blood everywhere in the land of Egypt, even in wooden and stone containers.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron did so, just as the Lord had commanded. He raised the staff and struck the water that was in the Nile right before the eyes of Pharaoh and his servants, and all the water that was in the Nile was turned to blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the fish that were in the Nile died, the Nile began to stink, so that the Egyptians could not drink water from the Nile. There was blood everywhere in the land of Egypt!
speaker: Narrator

text: But the magicians of Egypt did the same by their secret arts, and so Pharaoh’s heart remained hard, and he refused to listen to Moses and Aaron—just as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Pharaoh turned and went into his house. He did not pay any attention to this.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Egyptians dug around the Nile for water to drink, because they could not drink the water of the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seven full days passed after the Lord struck the Nile.
speaker: Narrator

text: (7:26) Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord has said: “Release my people in order that they may serve me!
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you refuse to release them, then I am going to plague all your territory with frogs.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Nile will swarm with frogs, and they will come up and go into your house, in your bedroom, and on your bed, and into the houses of your servants and your people, and into your ovens and your kneading troughs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Frogs will come up against you, your people, and all your servants.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Extend your hand with your staff over the rivers, over the canals, and over the ponds, and bring the frogs up over the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron extended his hand over the waters of Egypt, and frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The magicians did the same with their secret arts and brought up frogs on the land of Egypt too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Pray to the Lord that he may take the frogs away from me and my people, and I will release the people that they may sacrifice to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Pharaoh, “You may have the honor over me—when shall I pray for you, your servants, and your people, for the frogs to be removed from you and your houses, so that they will be left only in the Nile?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Tomorrow.” And Moses said, “It will be as you say, so that you may know that there is no one like the Lord our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The frogs will depart from you, your houses, your servants, and your people; they will be left only in the Nile.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried to the Lord because of the frogs that he had brought on Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did as Moses asked—the frogs died in the houses, the villages, and the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians piled them in countless heaps, and the land stank.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he hardened his heart and did not listen to them, just as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Extend your staff and strike the dust of the ground, and it will become gnats throughout all the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: They did so; Aaron extended his hand with his staff, he struck the dust of the ground, and it became gnats on people and on animals. All the dust of the ground became gnats throughout all the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the magicians attempted to bring forth gnats by their secret arts, they could not. So there were gnats on people and on animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The magicians said to Pharaoh, “It is the finger of God!” But Pharaoh’s heart remained hard, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had predicted.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning and position yourself before Pharaoh as he goes out to the water, and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord has said, “Release my people that they may serve me!
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do not release my people, then I am going to send swarms of flies on you and on your servants and on your people and in your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies, and even the ground they stand on.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on that day I will mark off the land of Goshen, where my people are staying, so that no swarms of flies will be there, that you may know that I am the Lord in the midst of this land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will put a division between my people and your people. This sign will take place tomorrow.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord did so; a thick swarm of flies came into Pharaoh’s house and into the houses of his servants, and throughout the whole land of Egypt the land was ruined because of the swarms of flies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Go, sacrifice to your God within the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “That would not be the right thing to do, for the sacrifices we make to the Lord our God would be an abomination to the Egyptians. If we make sacrifices that are an abomination to the Egyptians right before their eyes, will they not stone us?
speaker: Narrator

text: We must go on a three-day journey into the wilderness and sacrifice to the Lord our God, just as he is telling us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said, “I will release you so that you may sacrifice to the Lord your God in the wilderness. Only you must not go very far. Do pray for me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “I am going to go out from you and pray to the Lord, and the swarms of flies will go away from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people tomorrow. Only do not let Pharaoh deal falsely again by not releasing the people to sacrifice to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went out from Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord did as Moses asked—he removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, from his servants, and from his people. Not one remained!
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh hardened his heart this time also and did not release the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has said, “Release my people that they may serve me!
speaker: Narrator

text: For if you refuse to release them and continue holding them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then the hand of the Lord will surely bring a very terrible plague on your livestock in the field, on the horses, the donkeys, the camels, the herds, and the flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord will distinguish between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of Egypt, and nothing will die of all that the Israelites have.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord set an appointed time, saying, “Tomorrow the Lord will do this in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord did this on the next day; all the livestock of the Egyptians died, but of the Israelites’ livestock not one died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh sent representatives to investigate, and indeed, not even one of the livestock of Israel had died. But Pharaoh’s heart remained hard, and he did not release the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Take handfuls of soot from a furnace, and have Moses throw it into the air while Pharaoh is watching.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will become fine dust over the whole land of Egypt and will cause boils to break out and fester on both people and animals in all the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took soot from a furnace and stood before Pharaoh, Moses threw it into the air, and it caused festering boils to break out on both people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils, for boils were on the magicians and on all the Egyptians.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had predicted to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning, stand before Pharaoh, and tell him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has said: “Release my people so that they may serve me!
speaker: Narrator

text: For this time I will send all my plagues on your very self and on your servants and your people, so that you may know that there is no one like me in all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For by now I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with plague, and you would have been destroyed from the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for this purpose I have caused you to stand: to show you my strength, and so that my name may be declared in all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are still exalting yourself against my people by not releasing them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am going to cause very severe hail to rain down about this time tomorrow, such hail as has never occurred in Egypt from the day it was founded until now.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, send instructions to gather your livestock and all your possessions in the fields to a safe place. Every person or animal caught in the field and not brought into the house—the hail will come down on them, and they will die!”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Those of Pharaoh’s servants who feared the Lord’s message hurried to bring their servants and livestock into the houses,
speaker: Narrator

text: but those who did not take the Lord’s message seriously left their servants and their cattle in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Extend your hand toward the sky that there may be hail in all the land of Egypt, on people and on animals, and on everything that grows in the field in the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses extended his staff toward the sky, the Lord sent thunder and hail, and fire fell to the earth; so the Lord caused hail to rain down on the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hail fell and fire mingled with the hail; the hail was so severe that there had not been any like it in all the land of Egypt since it had become a nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hail struck everything in the open fields, both people and animals, throughout all the land of Egypt. The hail struck everything that grows in the field, and it broke all the trees of the field to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only in the land of Goshen, where the Israelites lived, was there no hail.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh sent and summoned Moses and Aaron and said to them, “I have sinned this time! The Lord is righteous, and I and my people are guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pray to the Lord, for the mighty thunderings and hail are too much! I will release you and you will stay no longer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to him, “When I leave the city I will spread my hands to the Lord, the thunder will cease, and there will be no more hail, so that you may know that the earth belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as for you and your servants, I know that you do not yet fear the Lord God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now the flax and the barley were struck by the hail, for the barley had ripened and the flax was in bud.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wheat and the spelt were not struck, for they are later crops.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses left Pharaoh, went out of the city, and spread out his hands to the Lord, and the thunder and the hail ceased, and the rain stopped pouring on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh saw that the rain and hail and thunder ceased, he sinned again: both he and his servants hardened their hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Pharaoh’s heart remained hard, and he did not release the Israelites, as the Lord had predicted through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh, for I have hardened his heart and the heart of his servants, in order to display these signs of mine before him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in order that in the hearing of your son and your grandson you may tell how I made fools of the Egyptians and about my signs that I displayed among them, so that you may know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron came to Pharaoh and told him, “This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has said: ‘How long do you refuse to humble yourself before me? Release my people so that they may serve me!
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you refuse to release my people, I am going to bring locusts into your territory tomorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will cover the surface of the earth, so that you will be unable to see the ground. They will eat the remainder of what escaped—what is left over for you—from the hail, and they will eat every tree that grows for you from the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will fill your houses, the houses of your servants, and all the houses of Egypt, such as neither your fathers nor your grandfathers have seen since they have been in the land until this day!’” Then Moses turned and went out from Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh’s servants said to him, “How long will this man be a menace to us? Release the people so that they may serve the Lord their God. Do you not know that Egypt is destroyed?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh, and he said to them, “Go, serve the Lord your God. Exactly who is going with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “We will go with our young and our old, with our sons and our daughters, and with our sheep and our cattle we will go, because we are to hold a pilgrim feast for the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “The Lord will need to be with you if I release you and your dependents! Watch out! Trouble is right in front of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: No! Go, you men only, and serve the Lord, for that is what you want.” Then Moses and Aaron were driven out of Pharaoh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Extend your hand over the land of Egypt for the locusts, that they may come up over the land of Egypt and eat everything that grows in the ground, everything that the hail has left.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses extended his staff over the land of Egypt, and then the Lord brought an east wind on the land all that day and all night. The morning came, and the east wind had brought up the locusts!
speaker: Narrator

text: The locusts went up over all the land of Egypt and settled down in all the territory of Egypt. It was very severe; there had been no locusts like them before, nor will there be such ever again.
speaker: Narrator

text: They covered the surface of all the ground so that the ground became dark with them, and they ate all the vegetation of the ground and all the fruit of the trees that the hail had left. Nothing green remained on the trees or on anything that grew in the fields throughout the whole land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh quickly summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “I have sinned against the Lord your God and against you!
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, forgive my sin this time only, and pray to the Lord your God that he would only take this death away from me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went out from Pharaoh and prayed to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord turned a very strong west wind, and it picked up the locusts and blew them into the Red Sea. Not one locust remained in all the territory of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not release the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Extend your hand toward heaven so that there may be darkness over the land of Egypt, a darkness so thick it can be felt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses extended his hand toward heaven, and there was absolute darkness throughout the land of Egypt for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one could see another person, and no one could rise from his place for three days. But the Israelites had light in the places where they lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and said, “Go, serve the Lord—only your flocks and herds will be detained. Even your families may go with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses said, “Will you also provide us with sacrifices and burnt offerings that we may present them to the Lord our God?
speaker: Narrator

text: Our livestock must also go with us! Not a hoof is to be left behind! For we must take these animals to serve the Lord our God. Until we arrive there, we do not know what we must use to serve the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he was not willing to release them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh said to him, “Go from me! Watch out for yourself! Do not appear before me again, for when you see my face you will die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “As you wish! I will not see your face again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “I will bring one more plague on Pharaoh and on Egypt; after that he will release you from this place. When he releases you, he will drive you out completely from this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Instruct the people that each man and each woman is to request from his or her neighbor items of silver and gold.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now the Lord granted the people favor with the Egyptians. Moreover, the man Moses was very great in the land of Egypt, respected by Pharaoh’s servants and by the Egyptian people.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘About midnight I will go throughout Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the firstborn in the land of Egypt will die, from the firstborn son of Pharaoh who sits on his throne, to the firstborn son of the slave girl who is at her hand mill, and all the firstborn of the cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: There will be a great cry throughout the whole land of Egypt, such as there has never been, nor ever will be again.
speaker: Narrator

text: But against any of the Israelites not even a dog will bark against either people or animals, so that you may know that the Lord distinguishes between Egypt and Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: All these your servants will come down to me and bow down to me, saying, ‘Go, you and all the people who follow you,’ and after that I will go out.” Then Moses went out from Pharaoh in great anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh will not listen to you, so that my wonders may be multiplied in the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron did all these wonders before Pharaoh, but the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not release the Israelites from his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This month is to be your beginning of months; it will be your first month of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Tell the whole community of Israel, ‘On the tenth day of this month they each must take a lamb for themselves according to their families—a lamb for each household.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any household is too small for a lamb, the man and his next-door neighbor are to take a lamb according to the number of people—you will make your count for the lamb according to how much each one can eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your lamb must be perfect, a male, one year old; you may take it from the sheep or from the goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must care for it until the fourteenth day of this month, and then the whole community of Israel will kill it around sundown.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will take some of the blood and put it on the two side posts and top of the doorframe of the houses where they will eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will eat the meat the same night; they will eat it roasted over the fire with bread made without yeast and with bitter herbs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not eat it raw or boiled in water, but roast it over the fire with its head, its legs, and its entrails.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must leave nothing until morning, but you must burn with fire whatever remains of it until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how you are to eat it—dressed to travel, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. You are to eat it in haste. It is the Lord’s Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘I will pass through the land of Egypt in the same night, and I will attack all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both of humans and of animals, and on all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgment. I am the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are, so that when I see the blood I will pass over you, and this plague will not fall on you to destroy you when I attack the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘This day will become a memorial for you, and you will celebrate it as a festival to the Lord—you will celebrate it perpetually as a lasting ordinance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you must eat bread made without yeast. Surely on the first day you must put away yeast from your houses because anyone who eats bread made with yeast from the first day to the seventh day will be cut off from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘On the first day there will be a holy convocation, and on the seventh day there will be a holy convocation for you. You must do no work of any kind on them, only what every person will eat—that alone may be prepared for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you will keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread, because on this very day I brought your regiments out from the land of Egypt, and so you must keep this day perpetually as a lasting ordinance.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first month, from the fourteenth day of the month, in the evening, you will eat bread made without yeast until the twenty-first day of the month in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days yeast must not be found in your houses, for whoever eats what is made with yeast—that person will be cut off from the community of Israel, whether a resident foreigner or one born in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not eat anything made with yeast; in all the places where you live you must eat bread made without yeast.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses summoned all the elders of Israel, and told them, “Go and select for yourselves a lamb or young goat for your families, and kill the Passover animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take a branch of hyssop, dip it in the blood that is in the basin, and apply to the top of the doorframe and the two side posts some of the blood that is in the basin. Not one of you is to go out the door of his house until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will pass through to strike Egypt, and when he sees the blood on the top of the doorframe and the two side posts, then the Lord will pass over the door, and he will not permit the destroyer to enter your houses to strike you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must observe this event as an ordinance for you and for your children forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you enter the land that the Lord will give to you, just as he said, you must observe this ceremony.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your children ask you, ‘What does this ceremony mean to you?’—
speaker: Narrator

text: then you will say, ‘It is the sacrifice of the Lord’s Passover, when he passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt, when he struck Egypt and delivered our households.’” The people bowed down low to the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Israelites went away and did exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: It happened at midnight—the Lord attacked all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sat on his throne to the firstborn of the captive who was in the prison, and all the firstborn of the cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh got up in the night, along with all his servants and all Egypt, and there was a great cry in Egypt, for there was no house in which there was not someone dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron in the night and said, “Get up, get out from among my people, both you and the Israelites! Go, serve the Lord as you have requested!
speaker: Narrator

text: Also, take your flocks and your herds, just as you have requested, and leave. But bless me also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians were urging the people on, in order to send them out of the land quickly, for they were saying, “We are all dead!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people took their dough before the yeast was added, with their kneading troughs bound up in their clothing on their shoulders.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Israelites had done as Moses told them—they had requested from the Egyptians silver and gold items and clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord gave the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, and they gave them whatever they wanted, and so they plundered Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites journeyed from Rameses to Sukkoth. There were about 600,000 men on foot, plus their dependents.
speaker: Narrator

text: A mixed multitude also went up with them, and flocks and herds—a very large number of cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: They baked cakes of bread without yeast using the dough they had brought from Egypt, for it was made without yeast. Because they were thrust out of Egypt and were not able to delay, they could not prepare food for themselves either.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the length of time the Israelites lived in Egypt was 430 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of the 430 years, on the very day, all the regiments of the Lord went out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was a night of vigil for the Lord to bring them out from the land of Egypt, and so on this night all Israel is to keep the vigil to the Lord for generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “This is the ordinance of the Passover. No foreigner may share in eating it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But everyone’s servant who is bought for money, after you have circumcised him, may eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: A foreigner and a hired worker must not eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be eaten in one house; you must not bring any of the meat outside the house, and you must not break a bone of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole community of Israel must observe it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a resident foreigner lives with you and wants to observe the Passover to the Lord, all his males must be circumcised, and then he may approach and observe it, and he will be like one who is born in the land—but no uncircumcised person may eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same law will apply to the person who is native-born and to the resident foreigner who lives among you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the Israelites did exactly as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on this very day the Lord brought the Israelites out of the land of Egypt by their regiments.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Set apart to me every firstborn male—the first offspring of every womb among the Israelites, whether human or animal; it is mine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the people, “Remember this day on which you came out from Egypt, from the place where you were enslaved, for the Lord brought you out of there with a mighty hand—and no bread made with yeast may be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: On this day, in the month of Abib, you are going out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord brings you to the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites, and Jebusites, which he swore to your fathers to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey, then you will keep this ceremony in this month.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you must eat bread made without yeast, and on the seventh day there is to be a festival to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bread made without yeast must be eaten for seven days; no bread made with yeast shall be seen among you, and you must have no yeast among you within any of your borders.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to tell your son on that day, ‘It is because of what the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt.’
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a sign for you on your hand and a memorial on your forehead, so that the law of the Lord may be in your mouth, for with a mighty hand the Lord brought you out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must keep this ordinance at its appointed time from year to year.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the Lord brings you into the land of the Canaanites, as he swore to you and to your fathers, and gives it to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: then you must give over to the Lord the first offspring of every womb. Every firstling of a beast that you have—the males will be the Lord’s.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every firstling of a donkey you must redeem with a lamb, and if you do not redeem it, then you must break its neck. Every firstborn of your sons you must redeem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In the future, when your son asks you ‘What is this?’ you are to tell him, ‘With a mighty hand the Lord brought us out from Egypt, from the land of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh stubbornly refused to release us, the Lord killed all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of people to the firstborn of animals. That is why I am sacrificing to the Lord the first male offspring of every womb, but all my firstborn sons I redeem.’
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be for a sign on your hand and for frontlets on your forehead, for with a mighty hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh released the people, God did not lead them by the way to the land of the Philistines, although that was nearby, for God said, “Lest the people change their minds and return to Egypt when they experience war.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So God brought the people around by the way of the wilderness to the Red Sea, and the Israelites went up from the land of Egypt prepared for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for Joseph had made the Israelites solemnly swear, “God will surely attend to you, and you will carry my bones up from this place with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They journeyed from Sukkoth and camped in Etham, on the edge of the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord was going before them by day in a pillar of cloud to lead them in the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they could travel day or night.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did not remove the pillar of cloud by day nor the pillar of fire by night from before the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites that they must turn and camp before Pi Hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea; you are to camp by the sea before Baal Zephon opposite it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pharaoh will think regarding the Israelites, ‘They are wandering around confused in the land—the desert has closed in on them.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and he will chase after them. I will gain honor because of Pharaoh and because of all his army, and the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.” So this is what they did.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was reported to the king of Egypt that the people had fled, the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was turned against the people, and the king and his servants said, “What in the world have we done? For we have released the people of Israel from serving us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he prepared his chariots and took his army with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took 600 select chariots, and all the rest of the chariots of Egypt, and officers on all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he chased after the Israelites. Now the Israelites were going out defiantly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians chased after them, and all the horses and chariots of Pharaoh and his horsemen and his army overtook them camping by the sea, beside Pi Hahiroth, before Baal Zephon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Pharaoh got closer, the Israelites looked up, and there were the Egyptians marching after them, and they were terrified. The Israelites cried out to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they said to Moses, “Is it because there are no graves in Egypt that you have taken us away to die in the desert? What in the world have you done to us by bringing us out of Egypt?
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t this what we told you in Egypt, ‘Leave us alone so that we can serve the Egyptians, because it is better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the desert!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the people, “Do not fear! Stand firm and see the salvation of the Lord that he will provide for you today; for the Egyptians that you see today you will never, ever see again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will fight for you, and you can be still.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Why do you cry out to me? Tell the Israelites to move on.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for you, lift up your staff and extend your hand toward the sea and divide it, so that the Israelites may go through the middle of the sea on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for me, I am going to harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will come after them, that I may be honored because of Pharaoh and his army and his chariots and his horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I have gained my honor because of Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of God, who was going before the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them, and the pillar of cloud moved from before them and stood behind them.
speaker: Narrator

text: It came between the Egyptian camp and the Israelite camp; it was a dark cloud and it lit up the night so that one camp did not come near the other the whole night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses stretched out his hand toward the sea, and the Lord drove the sea apart by a strong east wind all that night, and he made the sea into dry land, and the water was divided.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites went through the middle of the sea on dry ground, the water forming a wall for them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Egyptians chased them and followed them into the middle of the sea—all the horses of Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the morning watch the Lord looked down on the Egyptian army through the pillar of fire and cloud, and he threw the Egyptian army into a panic.
speaker: Narrator

text: He jammed the wheels of their chariots so that they had difficulty driving, and the Egyptians said, “Let’s flee from Israel, for the Lord fights for them against Egypt!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Extend your hand toward the sea, so that the waters may flow back on the Egyptians, on their chariots, and on their horsemen!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses extended his hand toward the sea, and the sea returned to its normal state when the sun began to rise. Now the Egyptians were fleeing before it, but the Lord overthrew the Egyptians in the middle of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water returned and covered the chariots and the horsemen and all the army of Pharaoh that was coming after the Israelites into the sea—not so much as one of them survived!
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites walked on dry ground in the middle of the sea, the water forming a wall for them on their right and on their left.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord saved Israel on that day from the power of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the shore of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel saw the great power that the Lord had exercised over the Egyptians, they feared the Lord, and they believed in the Lord and in his servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the Lord. They said,
“I will sing to the Lord, for he has triumphed gloriously,
the horse and its rider he has thrown into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is my strength and my song,
and he has become my salvation.
This is my God, and I will praise him,
my father’s God, and I will exalt him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is a warrior—
the Lord is his name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The chariots of Pharaoh and his army he has thrown into the sea,
and his chosen officers were drowned in the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The depths have covered them;
they went down to the bottom like a stone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your right hand, O Lord, was majestic in power;
your right hand, O Lord, shattered the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the abundance of your majesty you have overthrown
those who rise up against you.
You sent forth your wrath;
it consumed them like stubble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the blast of your nostrils the waters were piled up,
the flowing water stood upright like a heap,
and the deep waters were solidified in the heart of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The enemy said, ‘I will chase, I will overtake,
I will divide the spoil;
my desire will be satisfied on them.
I will draw my sword, my hand will destroy them.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you blew with your breath, and the sea covered them.
They sank like lead in the mighty waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is like you, O Lord, among the gods?
Who is like you—majestic in holiness, fearful in praises, working wonders?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You stretched out your right hand,
the earth swallowed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By your loyal love you will lead the people whom you have redeemed;
you will guide them by your strength to your holy dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nations will hear and tremble;
anguish will seize the inhabitants of Philistia.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the chiefs of Edom will be terrified,
trembling will seize the leaders of Moab,
and the inhabitants of Canaan will shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear and dread will fall on them;
by the greatness of your arm they will be as still as stone
until your people pass by, O Lord,
until the people whom you have bought pass by.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will bring them in and plant them in the mountain of your inheritance,
in the place you made for your residence, O Lord,
the sanctuary, O Lord, that your hands have established.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will reign forever and ever!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the horses of Pharaoh came with his chariots and his footmen into the sea,
and the Lord brought back the waters of the sea on them,
but the Israelites walked on dry land in the middle of the sea.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a hand drum in her hand, and all the women went out after her with hand drums and with dances.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Then Moses led Israel to journey away from the Red Sea. They went out to the wilderness of Shur, walked for three days into the wilderness, and found no water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to Marah, but they were not able to drink the waters of Marah, because they were bitter. (That is why its name was Marah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people murmured against Moses, saying, “What can we drink?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He cried out to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a tree. When Moses threw it into the water, the water became safe to drink. There the Lord made for them a binding ordinance, and there he tested them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If you will diligently obey the Lord your God, and do what is right in his sight, and pay attention to his commandments, and keep all his statutes, then all the diseases that I brought on the Egyptians I will not bring on you, for I, the Lord, am your healer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve wells of water and seventy palm trees, and they camped there by the water.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they journeyed from Elim, the entire company of Israelites came to the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, on the fifteenth day of the second month after their exodus from the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire company of Israelites murmured against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to them, “If only we had died by the hand of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat by the pots of meat, when we ate bread to the full, for you have brought us out into this wilderness to kill this whole assembly with hunger!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “I am going to rain bread from heaven for you, and the people will go out and gather the amount for each day, so that I may test them. Will they walk in my law or not?
speaker: Narrator

text: On the sixth day they will prepare what they bring in, and it will be twice as much as they gather every other day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron said to all the Israelites, “In the evening you will know that the Lord has brought you out of the land of Egypt,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the morning you will see the glory of the Lord, because he has heard your murmurings against the Lord. As for us, what are we, that you should murmur against us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “You will know this when the Lord gives you meat to eat in the evening and bread in the morning to satisfy you, because the Lord has heard your murmurings that you are murmuring against him. As for us, what are we? Your murmurings are not against us, but against the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Tell the whole community of the Israelites, ‘Come before the Lord, because he has heard your murmurings.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: As Aaron spoke to the whole community of the Israelites and they looked toward the wilderness, there the glory of the Lord appeared in the cloud,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have heard the murmurings of the Israelites. Tell them, ‘During the evening you will eat meat, and in the morning you will be satisfied with bread, so that you may know that I am the Lord your God.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the evening the quail came up and covered the camp, and in the morning a layer of dew was all around the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the layer of dew had evaporated, there on the surface of the wilderness was a thin flaky substance, thin like frost on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites saw it, they said to one another, “What is it?” because they did not know what it was. Moses said to them, “It is the bread that the Lord has given you for food.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘Each person is to gather from it what he can eat, an omer per person according to the number of your people; each one will pick it up for whoever lives in his tent.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites did so, and they gathered—some more, some less.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they measured with an omer, the one who gathered much had nothing left over, and the one who gathered little lacked nothing; each one had gathered what he could eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to them, “No one is to keep any of it until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they did not listen to Moses; some kept part of it until morning, and it was full of worms and began to stink, and Moses was angry with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they gathered it each morning, each person according to what he could eat, and when the sun got hot, it would melt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the sixth day they gathered twice as much food, two omers per person; and all the leaders of the community came and told Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘Tomorrow is a time of cessation from work, a holy Sabbath to the Lord. Whatever you want to bake, bake today; whatever you want to boil, boil today; whatever is left put aside for yourselves to be kept until morning.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they put it aside until the morning, just as Moses had commanded, and it did not stink, nor were there any worms in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “Eat it today, for today is a Sabbath to the Lord; today you will not find it in the area.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days you will gather it, but on the seventh day, the Sabbath, there will not be any.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day some of the people went out to gather it, but they found nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord said to Moses, “How long do you refuse to obey my commandments and my instructions?
speaker: Narrator

text: See, because the Lord has given you the Sabbath, that is why he is giving you food for two days on the sixth day. Each of you stay where you are; let no one go out of his place on the seventh day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house of Israel called its name “manna.” It was like coriander seed and was white, and it tasted like wafers with honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded: ‘Fill an omer with it to be kept for generations to come, so that they may see the food I fed you in the wilderness when I brought you out from the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “Take a jar and put in it an omer full of manna, and place it before the Lord to be kept for generations to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just as the Lord commanded Moses, so Aaron placed it before the ark of the testimony for safekeeping.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Israelites ate manna forty years, until they came to a land that was inhabited; they ate manna until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: (Now an omer is one-tenth of an ephah.)
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole community of the Israelites traveled on their journey from the wilderness of Sin according to the Lord’s instruction, and they pitched camp in Rephidim. Now there was no water for the people to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people contended with Moses, and they said, “Give us water to drink!” Moses said to them, “Why do you contend with me? Why do you test the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people were very thirsty there for water, and they murmured against Moses and said, “Why in the world did you bring us up from Egypt—to kill us and our children and our cattle with thirst?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses cried out to the Lord, “What will I do with this people?—a little more and they will stone me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go over before the people; take with you some of the elders of Israel and take in your hand your staff with which you struck the Nile and go.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be standing before you there on the rock in Horeb, and you will strike the rock, and water will come out of it so that the people may drink.” And Moses did so in plain view of the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called the name of the place Massah and Meribah, because of the contending of the Israelites and because of their testing the Lord, saying, “Is the Lord among us or not?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Amalek came and attacked Israel in Rephidim.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to Joshua, “Choose some of our men and go out, fight against Amalek. Tomorrow I will stand on top of the hill with the staff of God in my hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua fought against Amalek just as Moses had instructed him, and Moses and Aaron and Hur went up to the top of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever Moses would raise his hands, then Israel prevailed, but whenever he would rest his hands, then Amalek prevailed.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the hands of Moses became heavy, they took a stone and put it under him, and Aaron and Hur held up his hands, one on one side and one on the other, and so his hands were steady until the sun went down.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joshua destroyed Amalek and his army with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Write this as a memorial in the book, and rehearse it in Joshua’s hearing; for I will surely wipe out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses built an altar, and he called it “The Lord is my Banner,”
speaker: Narrator

text: for he said, “For a hand was lifted up to the throne of the Lord—that the Lord will have war with Amalek from generation to generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro, the priest of Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard about all that God had done for Moses and for his people Israel, that the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, took Moses’ wife Zipporah after he had sent her back,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her two sons, one of whom was named Gershom (for Moses had said, “I have been a foreigner in a foreign land”)
speaker: Narrator

text: and the other Eliezer (for Moses had said, “The God of my father has been my help and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh”).
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, together with Moses’ sons and his wife, came to Moses in the wilderness where he was camping by the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Moses, “I, your father-in-law Jethro, am coming to you, along with your wife and her two sons with her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went out to meet his father-in-law and bowed down and kissed him; they each asked about the other’s welfare, and then they went into the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told his father-in-law all that the Lord had done to Pharaoh and to Egypt for Israel’s sake, and all the hardship that had come on them along the way, and how the Lord had delivered them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro rejoiced because of all the good that the Lord had done for Israel, whom he had delivered from the hand of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jethro said, “Blessed be the Lord who has delivered you from the hand of Egypt, and from the hand of Pharaoh, who has delivered the people from the Egyptians’ control!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I know that the Lord is greater than all the gods, for in the thing in which they dealt proudly against them he has destroyed them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and sacrifices for God, and Aaron and all the elders of Israel came to eat food with the father-in-law of Moses before God.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day Moses sat to judge the people, and the people stood around Moses from morning until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses’ father-in-law saw all that he was doing for the people, he said, “What is this that you are doing for the people? Why are you sitting by yourself, and all the people stand around you from morning until evening?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to his father-in-law, “Because the people come to me to inquire of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they have a dispute, it comes to me and I decide between a man and his neighbor, and I make known the decrees of God and his laws.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses’ father-in-law said to him, “What you are doing is not good!
speaker: Narrator

text: You will surely wear out, both you and these people who are with you, for this is too heavy a burden for you; you are not able to do it by yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now listen to me, I will give you advice, and may God be with you. You be a representative for the people to God, and you bring their disputes to God;
speaker: Narrator

text: warn them of the statutes and the laws, and make known to them the way in which they must walk and the work they must do.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you choose from the people capable men, God-fearing men, men of truth, those who hate bribes, and put them over the people as rulers of thousands, rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will judge the people under normal circumstances, and every difficult case they will bring to you, but every small case they themselves will judge, so that you may make it easier for yourself, and they will bear the burden with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do this thing, and God so commands you, then you will be able to endure, and all these people will be able to go home satisfied.”
speaker: Narrator
