text: Moses listened to his father-in-law and did everything he had said.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses chose capable men from all Israel, and he made them heads over the people, rulers of thousands, rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens.
speaker: Narrator

text: They judged the people under normal circumstances; the difficult cases they would bring to Moses, but every small case they would judge themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses sent his father-in-law on his way, and so Jethro went to his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the third month after the Israelites went out from the land of Egypt, on the very day, they came to the desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they journeyed from Rephidim, they came to the desert of Sinai, and they camped in the desert; Israel camped there in front of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went up to God, and the Lord called to him from the mountain, “Thus you will tell the house of Jacob, and declare to the people of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘You yourselves have seen what I did to Egypt and how I lifted you on eagles’ wings and brought you to myself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, if you will diligently listen to me and keep my covenant, then you will be my special possession out of all the nations, for all the earth is mine,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you will be to me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.’ These are the words that you will speak to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses came and summoned the elders of Israel. He set before them all these words that the Lord had commanded him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and all the people answered together, “All that the Lord has commanded we will do!” So Moses brought the words of the people back to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “I am going to come to you in a dense cloud, so that the people may hear when I speak with you and so that they will always believe in you.” And Moses told the words of the people to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go to the people and sanctify them today and tomorrow, and make them wash their clothes
speaker: Narrator

text: and be ready for the third day, for on the third day the Lord will come down on Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must set boundaries for the people all around, saying, ‘Take heed to yourselves not to go up on the mountain nor touch its edge. Whoever touches the mountain will surely be put to death!
speaker: Narrator

text: No hand will touch him—but he will surely be stoned or shot through, whether a beast or a human being; he must not live.’ When the ram’s horn sounds a long blast they may go up on the mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses went down from the mountain to the people and sanctified the people, and they washed their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to the people, “Be ready for the third day. Do not approach your wives for marital relations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day in the morning there was thunder and lightning and a dense cloud on the mountain, and the sound of a very loud horn; all the people who were in the camp trembled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses brought the people out of the camp to meet God, and they took their place at the foot of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Mount Sinai was completely covered with smoke because the Lord had descended on it in fire, and its smoke went up like the smoke of a great furnace, and the whole mountain shook violently.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sound of the horn grew louder and louder, Moses was speaking and God was answering him with a voice.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord came down on Mount Sinai, on the top of the mountain, and the Lord summoned Moses to the top of the mountain, and Moses went up.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go down and solemnly warn the people, lest they force their way through to the Lord to look, and many of them perish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the priests also, who approach the Lord, sanctify themselves, lest the Lord break through against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “The people are not able to come up to Mount Sinai, because you solemnly warned us, ‘Set boundaries for the mountain and set it apart.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “Go, get down, and then come up, and Aaron with you, but do not let the priests and the people force their way through to come up to the Lord, lest he break through against them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses went down to the people and spoke to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: God spoke all these words:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I, the Lord, am your God, who brought you from the land of Egypt, from the house of slavery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall have no other gods before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not make for yourself a carved image or any likeness of anything that is in heaven above or that is on the earth beneath or that is in the water below.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall not bow down to them or serve them, for I, the Lord, your God, am a jealous God, responding to the transgression of fathers by dealing with children to the third and fourth generations of those who reject me,
speaker: Narrator

text: and showing covenant faithfulness to a thousand generations of those who love me and keep my commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain, for the Lord will not hold guiltless anyone who takes his name in vain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Remember the Sabbath day to set it apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For six days you may labor and do all your work,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the seventh day is a Sabbath to the Lord your God; on it you shall not do any work, you, or your son, or your daughter, or your male servant, or your female servant, or your cattle, or the resident foreigner who is in your gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth and the sea and all that is in them, and he rested on the seventh day; therefore the Lord blessed the Sabbath day and set it apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Honor your father and your mother, that you may live a long time in the land the Lord your God is giving to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not murder.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not commit adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not give false testimony against your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You shall not covet your neighbor’s house. You shall not covet your neighbor’s wife, nor his male servant, nor his female servant, nor his ox, nor his donkey, nor anything that belongs to your neighbor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people were seeing the thundering and the lightning, and heard the sound of the horn, and saw the mountain smoking—and when the people saw it they trembled with fear and kept their distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to Moses, “You speak to us and we will listen, but do not let God speak with us, lest we die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the people, “Do not fear, for God has come to test you, that the fear of him may be before you so that you do not sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people kept their distance, but Moses drew near the thick darkness where God was.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Thus you will tell the Israelites: ‘You yourselves have seen that I have spoken with you from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not make gods of silver alongside me, nor make gods of gold for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘You must make for me an altar made of earth, and you will sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and your peace offerings, your sheep and your cattle. In every place where I cause my name to be honored I will come to you and I will bless you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you make me an altar of stone, you must not build it of stones shaped with tools, for if you use your tool on it you have defiled it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must not go up by steps to my altar, so that your nakedness is not exposed.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the ordinances that you will set before them:
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you buy a Hebrew servant, he is to serve you for six years, but in the seventh year he will go out free without paying anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he came in by himself he will go out by himself; if he had a wife when he came in, then his wife will go out with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If his master gave him a wife, and she bore sons or daughters, the wife and the children will belong to her master, and he will go out by himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the servant should declare, ‘I love my master, my wife, and my children; I will not go out free,’
speaker: Narrator

text: then his master must bring him to the judges, and he will bring him to the door or the doorpost, and his master will pierce his ear with an awl, and he shall serve him forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man sells his daughter as a female servant, she will not go out as the male servants do.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she does not please her master, who has designated her for himself, then he must let her be redeemed. He has no right to sell her to a foreign nation, because he has dealt deceitfully with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he designated her for his son, then he will deal with her according to the customary rights of daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he takes another wife, he must not diminish the first one’s food, her clothing, or her marital rights.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he does not provide her with these three things, then she will go out free, without paying money.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever strikes someone so that he dies must surely be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he does not do it with premeditation, but it happens by accident, then I will appoint for you a place where he may flee.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a man willfully attacks his neighbor to kill him cunningly, you will take him even from my altar that he may die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever strikes his father or his mother must surely be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever kidnaps someone and sells him, or is caught still holding him, must surely be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever treats his father or his mother disgracefully must surely be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If men fight, and one strikes his neighbor with a stone or with his fist and he does not die, but must remain in bed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and then if he gets up and walks about outside on his staff, then the one who struck him is innocent, except he must pay for the injured person’s loss of time and see to it that he is fully healed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man strikes his male servant or his female servant with a staff so that he or she dies as a result of the blow, he will surely be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if the injured servant survives one or two days, the owner will not be punished, for he has suffered the loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If men fight and hit a pregnant woman and her child is born prematurely, but there is no serious injury, the one who hit her will surely be punished in accordance with what the woman’s husband demands of him, and he will pay what the court decides.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if there is serious injury, then you will give a life for a life,
speaker: Narrator

text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: burn for burn, wound for wound, bruise for bruise.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man strikes the eye of his male servant or his female servant so that he destroys it, he will let the servant go free as compensation for the eye.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he knocks out the tooth of his male servant or his female servant, he will let the servant go free as compensation for the tooth.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If an ox gores a man or a woman so that either dies, then the ox must surely be stoned and its flesh must not be eaten, but the owner of the ox will be acquitted.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the ox had the habit of goring, and its owner was warned but he did not take the necessary precautions, and then it killed a man or a woman, the ox must be stoned and the man must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a ransom is set for him, then he must pay the redemption for his life according to whatever amount was set for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the ox gores a son or a daughter, the owner will be dealt with according to this rule.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the ox gores a male servant or a female servant, the owner must pay thirty shekels of silver, and the ox must be stoned.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man opens a pit or if a man digs a pit and does not cover it and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
speaker: Narrator

text: the owner of the pit must repay the loss. He must give money to its owner, and the dead animal will become his.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the ox of one man injures the ox of his neighbor so that it dies, then they will sell the live ox and divide its proceeds, and they will also divide the dead ox.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or if it is known that the ox had the habit of goring, and its owner did not take the necessary precautions, he must surely pay ox for ox, and the dead animal will become his.
speaker: Narrator

text: (21:37) “If a man steals an ox or a sheep and kills it or sells it, he must pay back five head of cattle for the ox, and four sheep for the one sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a thief is caught breaking in and is struck so that he dies, there will be no blood guilt for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the sun has risen on him, then there is blood guilt for him. A thief must surely make full restitution; if he has nothing, then he will be sold for his theft.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the stolen item should in fact be found alive in his possession, whether it be an ox or a donkey or a sheep, he must pay back double.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man grazes his livestock in a field or a vineyard and he lets the livestock loose and they graze in the field of another man, he must make restitution from the best of his own field and the best of his own vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a fire breaks out and spreads to thorn bushes, so that stacked grain or standing grain or the whole field is consumed, the one who started the fire must surely make restitution.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man gives his neighbor money or articles for safekeeping and it is stolen from the man’s house, if the thief is caught, he must repay double.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the thief is not caught, then the owner of the house will be brought before the judges to see whether he has laid his hand on his neighbor’s goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all cases of illegal possessions, whether for an ox, a donkey, a sheep, a garment, or any kind of lost item, about which someone says ‘This belongs to me,’ the matter of the two of them will come before the judges, and the one whom the judges declare guilty must repay double to his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man gives his neighbor a donkey or an ox or a sheep or any beast to keep, and it dies or is injured or is carried away without anyone seeing it,
speaker: Narrator

text: then there will be an oath to the Lord between the two of them, that he has not laid his hand on his neighbor’s goods, and its owner will accept this, and he will not have to pay.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it was stolen from him, he will pay its owner.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is torn in pieces, then he will bring it for evidence, and he will not have to pay for what was torn.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man borrows an animal from his neighbor and it is hurt or dies when its owner was not with it, the man who borrowed it will surely pay.
speaker: Narrator

text: If its owner was with it, he will not have to pay; if it was hired, what was paid for the hire covers it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man seduces a virgin who is not engaged and goes to bed with her, he must surely pay the marriage price for her to be his wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: If her father refuses to give her to him, he must pay money for the bride price of virgins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not allow a sorceress to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever has sexual relations with a beast must surely be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever sacrifices to a god other than the Lord alone must be utterly destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not wrong a resident foreigner nor oppress him, for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not afflict any widow or orphan.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you afflict them in any way and they cry to me, I will surely hear their cry,
speaker: Narrator

text: and my anger will burn and I will kill you with the sword, and your wives will be widows and your children will be fatherless.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you lend money to any of my people who are needy among you, do not be like a moneylender to him; do not charge him interest.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you do take the garment of your neighbor in pledge, you must return it to him by the time the sun goes down,
speaker: Narrator

text: for it is his only covering—it is his garment for his body. What else can he sleep in? And when he cries out to me, I will hear, for I am gracious.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not blaspheme God or curse the ruler of your people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not hold back offerings from your granaries or your vats. You must give me the firstborn of your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must also do this for your oxen and for your sheep; seven days they may remain with their mothers, but give them to me on the eighth day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You will be holy people to me; you must not eat any meat torn by animals in the field. You must throw it to the dogs.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not give a false report. Do not make common cause with the wicked to be a malicious witness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not follow a crowd in doing evil things; in a lawsuit you must not offer testimony that agrees with a crowd so as to pervert justice,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you must not show partiality to a poor man in his lawsuit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you encounter your enemy’s ox or donkey wandering off, you must by all means return it to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you see the donkey of someone who hates you fallen under its load, you must not ignore him, but be sure to help him with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not turn away justice for your poor people in their lawsuits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep your distance from a false charge—do not kill the innocent and the righteous, for I will not justify the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not accept a bribe, for a bribe blinds those who see and subverts the words of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not oppress a resident foreigner, since you know the life of a foreigner, for you were foreigners in the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For six years you are to sow your land and gather in its produce.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the seventh year you must let it lie fallow and leave it alone so that the poor of your people may eat, and what they leave any animal in the field may eat; you must do likewise with your vineyard and your olive grove.
speaker: Narrator

text: For six days you are to do your work, but on the seventh day you must cease, in order that your ox and your donkey may rest and that your female servant’s son and the resident foreigner may refresh themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pay attention to do everything I have told you, and do not even mention the names of other gods—do not let them be heard on your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Three times in the year you must make a pilgrim feast to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to observe the Feast of Unleavened Bread; seven days you must eat bread made without yeast, as I commanded you, at the appointed time of the month of Abib, for at that time you came out of Egypt. No one may appear before me empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are also to observe the Feast of Harvest, the firstfruits of your labors that you have sown in the field, and the Feast of Ingathering at the end of the year when you have gathered in your harvest out of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: At three times in the year all your males will appear before the Sovereign Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not offer the blood of my sacrifice with bread containing yeast; the fat of my festal sacrifice must not remain until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first of the firstfruits of your soil you must bring to the house of the Lord your God.
“You must not cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am going to send an angel before you to protect you as you journey and to bring you into the place that I have prepared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take heed because of him, and obey his voice; do not rebel against him, for he will not pardon your transgressions, for my Name is in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you diligently obey him and do all that I command, then I will be an enemy to your enemies, and I will be an adversary to your adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: For my angel will go before you and bring you to the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, and I will destroy them completely.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not bow down to their gods; you must not serve them or do according to their practices. Instead you must completely overthrow them and smash their standing stones to pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must serve the Lord your God, and he will bless your bread and your water, and I will remove sickness from your midst.
speaker: Narrator

text: No woman will miscarry her young or be barren in your land. I will fulfill the number of your days.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will send my terror before you, and I will alarm all the people whom you encounter; I will make all your enemies turn their backs to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send hornets before you that will drive out the Hivite, the Canaanite, and the Hittite before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not drive them out before you in one year, lest the land become desolate and the wild animals multiply against you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Little by little I will drive them out before you, until you become fruitful and inherit the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will set your boundaries from the Red Sea to the Sea of the Philistines, and from the desert to the River, for I will deliver the inhabitants of the land into your hand, and you will drive them out before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must make no covenant with them or with their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must not live in your land, lest they make you sin against me, for if you serve their gods, it will surely be a snare to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But to Moses the Lord said, “Come up to the Lord, you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel, and worship from a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses alone may come near the Lord, but the others must not come near, nor may the people go up with him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses came and told the people all the Lord’s words and all the decisions. All the people answered together, “We are willing to do all the words that the Lord has said,”
speaker: Narrator

text: and Moses wrote down all the words of the Lord. Early in the morning he built an altar at the foot of the mountain and arranged twelve standing stones—according to the twelve tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent young Israelite men, and they offered burnt offerings and sacrificed young bulls for peace offerings to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took half of the blood and put it in bowls, and half of the blood he splashed on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the Book of the Covenant and read it aloud to the people, and they said, “We are willing to do and obey all that the Lord has spoken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the blood and splashed it on the people and said, “This is the blood of the covenant that the Lord has made with you in accordance with all these words.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and the seventy elders of Israel went up,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they saw the God of Israel. Under his feet there was something like a pavement made of sapphire, clear like the sky itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not lay a hand on the leaders of the Israelites, so they saw God, and they ate and they drank.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Come up to me on the mountain and remain there, and I will give you the stone tablets with the law and the commandments that I have written, so that you may teach them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses set out with Joshua his attendant, and Moses went up the mountain of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the elders, “Wait for us in this place until we return to you. Here are Aaron and Hur with you. Whoever has any matters of dispute can approach them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went up the mountain, and the cloud covered the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: The glory of the Lord resided on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it for six days. On the seventh day he called to Moses from within the cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the appearance of the glory of the Lord was like a devouring fire on the top of the mountain in plain view of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses went into the cloud when he went up the mountain, and Moses was on the mountain forty days and forty nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites to take an offering for me; from every person motivated by a willing heart you are to receive my offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the offering you are to accept from them: gold, silver, bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: blue, purple, scarlet, fine linen, goats’ hair,
speaker: Narrator

text: ram skins dyed red, fine leather, acacia wood,
speaker: Narrator

text: oil for the light, spices for the anointing oil and for fragrant incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: onyx stones, and other gems to be set in the ephod and in the breastpiece.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let them make for me a sanctuary, so that I may live among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: According to all that I am showing you—the pattern of the tabernacle and the pattern of all its furnishings—you must make it exactly so.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They are to make an ark of acacia wood—its length is to be 45 inches, its width 27 inches, and its height 27 inches.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to overlay it with pure gold—both inside and outside you must overlay it, and you are to make a surrounding border of gold over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to cast four gold rings for it and put them on its four feet, with two rings on one side and two rings on the other side.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make poles of acacia wood, overlay them with gold,
speaker: Narrator

text: and put the poles into the rings at the sides of the ark in order to carry the ark with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles must remain in the rings of the ark; they must not be removed from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put into the ark the testimony that I will give to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make an atonement lid of pure gold; its length is to be 45 inches, and its width is to be 27 inches.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make two cherubim of gold; you are to make them of hammered metal on the two ends of the atonement lid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make one cherub on one end and one cherub on the other end; from the atonement lid you are to make the cherubim on the two ends.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cherubim are to be spreading their wings upward, overshadowing the atonement lid with their wings, and the cherubim are to face each other, looking toward the atonement lid.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put the atonement lid on top of the ark, and in the ark you are to put the testimony I am giving you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will meet with you there, and from above the atonement lid, from between the two cherubim that are over the ark of the testimony, I will speak with you about all that I will command you for the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make a table of acacia wood; its length is to be 36 inches, its width 18 inches, and its height 27 inches.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to overlay it with pure gold, and you are to make a surrounding border of gold for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make a surrounding frame for it about three inches broad, and you are to make a surrounding border of gold for its frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make four rings of gold for it and attach the rings at the four corners where its four legs are.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rings are to be close to the frame to provide places for the poles to carry the table.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold, so that the table may be carried with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make its plates, its ladles, its pitchers, and its bowls, to be used in pouring out offerings; you are to make them of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to set the Bread of the Presence on the table before me continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make a lampstand of pure gold. The lampstand is to be made of hammered metal; its base and its shaft, its cups, its buds, and its blossoms are to be from the same piece.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six branches are to extend from the sides of the lampstand, three branches of the lampstand from one side of it and three branches of the lampstand from the other side of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three cups shaped like almond flowers with buds and blossoms are to be on one branch, and three cups shaped like almond flowers with buds and blossoms are to be on the next branch, and the same for the six branches extending from the lampstand.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the lampstand there are to be four cups shaped like almond flowers with buds and blossoms,
speaker: Narrator

text: with a bud under the first two branches from it, and a bud under the next two branches from it, and a bud under the third two branches from it, according to the six branches that extend from the lampstand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their buds and their branches will be one piece, all of it one hammered piece of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make its seven lamps and then set its lamps up on it, so that it will give light to the area in front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its trimmers and its trays are to be of pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: About seventy-five pounds of pure gold is to be used for it and for all these utensils.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now be sure to make them according to the pattern you were shown on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The tabernacle itself you are to make with ten curtains of fine twisted linen and blue and purple and scarlet; you are to make them with cherubim that are the work of an artistic designer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of each curtain is to be 42 feet, and the width of each curtain is to be 6 feet—the same size for each of the curtains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five curtains are to be joined, one to another, and the other five curtains are to be joined, one to another.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make loops of blue material along the edge of the end curtain in one set, and in the same way you are to make loops in the outer edge of the end curtain in the second set.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make fifty loops on the one curtain, and you are to make fifty loops on the end curtain which is on the second set, so that the loops are opposite one to another.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make fifty gold clasps and join the curtains together with the clasps, so that the tabernacle is a unit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make curtains of goats’ hair for a tent over the tabernacle; you are to make eleven curtains.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of each curtain is to be 45 feet, and the width of each curtain is to be 6 feet—the same size for the eleven curtains.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to join five curtains by themselves and six curtains by themselves. You are to double over the sixth curtain at the front of the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make fifty loops along the edge of the end curtain in one set and fifty loops along the edge of the curtain that joins the second set.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make fifty bronze clasps and put the clasps into the loops and join the tent together so that it is a unit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the part that remains of the curtains of the tent—the half curtain that remains will hang over at the back of the tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foot and a half on the one side and the foot and a half on the other side of what remains in the length of the curtains of the tent will hang over the sides of the tabernacle, on one side and the other side, to cover it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make a covering for the tent out of ram skins dyed red and over that a covering of fine leather.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make the frames for the tabernacle out of acacia wood as uprights.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each frame is to be 15 feet long, and each frame is to be 27 inches wide,
speaker: Narrator

text: with two projections per frame parallel one to another. You are to make all the frames of the tabernacle in this way.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you are to make the frames for the tabernacle: twenty frames for the south side,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you are to make forty silver bases to go under the twenty frames—two bases under the first frame for its two projections, and likewise two bases under the next frame for its two projections;
speaker: Narrator

text: and for the second side of the tabernacle, the north side, twenty frames,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their forty silver bases, two bases under the first frame, and two bases under the next frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: And for the back of the tabernacle on the west you will make six frames.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make two frames for the corners of the tabernacle on the back.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the two corners they must be doubled at the lower end and finished together at the top in one ring. So it will be for both.
speaker: Narrator

text: So there are to be eight frames and their silver bases, sixteen bases, two bases under the first frame, and two bases under the next frame.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make bars of acacia wood, five for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
speaker: Narrator

text: and five bars for the frames on the second side of the tabernacle, and five bars for the frames on the back of the tabernacle on the west.
speaker: Narrator

text: The middle bar in the center of the frames will reach from end to end.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to overlay the frames with gold and make their rings of gold to provide places for the bars, and you are to overlay the bars with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to set up the tabernacle according to the plan that you were shown on the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make a special curtain of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine twisted linen; it is to be made with cherubim, the work of an artistic designer.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to hang it with gold hooks on four posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold, set in four silver bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to hang this curtain under the clasps and bring the ark of the testimony in there behind the curtain. The curtain will make a division for you between the Holy Place and the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put the atonement lid on the ark of the testimony in the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put the table outside the curtain and the lampstand on the south side of the tabernacle, opposite the table, and you are to place the table on the north side.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make a hanging for the entrance of the tent of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine twisted linen, the work of an embroiderer.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make for the hanging five posts of acacia wood and overlay them with gold, and their hooks will be gold, and you are to cast five bronze bases for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make the altar of acacia wood, 7½ feet long, and 7½ feet wide; the altar is to be square, and its height is to be 4½ feet .
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make its four horns on its four corners; its horns will be part of it, and you are to overlay it with bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make its pots for the ashes, its shovels, its tossing bowls, its meat hooks, and its fire pans—you are to make all its utensils of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make a grating for it, a network of bronze, and you are to make on the network four bronze rings on its four corners.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put it under the ledge of the altar below, so that the network will come halfway up the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make poles for the altar, poles of acacia wood, and you are to overlay them with bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles are to be put into the rings so that the poles will be on two sides of the altar when carrying it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make the altar hollow, out of boards. Just as it was shown you on the mountain, so they must make it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make the courtyard of the tabernacle. For the south side there are to be hangings for the courtyard of fine twisted linen, 150 feet long for one side,
speaker: Narrator

text: with twenty posts and their twenty bronze bases, with the hooks of the posts and their bands of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: Likewise for its length on the north side, there are to be hangings for 150 feet, with twenty posts and their twenty bronze bases, with silver hooks and bands on the posts.
speaker: Narrator

text: The width of the court on the west side is to be 75 feet with hangings, with their ten posts and their ten bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: The width of the court on the east side, toward the sunrise, is to be 75 feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: The hangings on one side of the gate are to be 22½ feet long, with their three posts and their three bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the second side there are to be hangings 22½ feet long, with their three posts and their three bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the gate of the courtyard there is to be a curtain of 30 feet, of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn and fine twisted linen, the work of an embroiderer, with four posts and their four bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the posts around the courtyard are to have silver bands; their hooks are to be silver, and their bases bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of the courtyard is to be 150 feet and the width 75 feet, and the height of the fine twisted linen hangings is to be 7½ feet, with their bronze bases.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the utensils of the tabernacle used in all its service, all its tent pegs, and all the tent pegs of the courtyard are to be made of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to command the Israelites that they bring to you pure oil of pressed olives for the light, so that the lamps will burn regularly.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the tent of meeting outside the curtain that is before the testimony, Aaron and his sons are to arrange it from evening to morning before the Lord. This is to be a lasting ordinance among the Israelites for generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you, bring near to you your brother Aaron and his sons with him from among the Israelites, so that they may minister as my priests—Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar, Aaron’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must make holy garments for your brother Aaron, for glory and for beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to speak to all who are specially skilled, whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom, so that they may make Aaron’s garments to set him apart to minister as my priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these are the garments that they are to make: a breastpiece, an ephod, a robe, a fitted tunic, a turban, and a sash. They are to make holy garments for your brother Aaron and for his sons, that they may minister as my priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: The artisans are to use the gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine linen.
speaker: Narrator

text: “They are to make the ephod of gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twisted linen, the work of an artistic designer.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is to have two shoulder pieces attached to two of its corners, so it can be joined together.
speaker: Narrator

text: The artistically woven waistband of the ephod that is on it is to be like it, of one piece with the ephod, of gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twisted linen.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to take two onyx stones and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: six of their names on one stone, and the six remaining names on the second stone, according to the order of their birth.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to engrave the two stones with the names of the sons of Israel with the work of an engraver in stone, like the engravings of a seal; you are to have them set in gold filigree settings.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put the two stones on the shoulders of the ephod, stones of memorial for the sons of Israel, and Aaron will bear their names before the Lord on his two shoulders for a memorial.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make filigree settings of gold
speaker: Narrator

text: and two braided chains of pure gold, like a cord, and attach the chains to the settings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make a breastpiece for use in making decisions, the work of an artistic designer; you are to make it in the same fashion as the ephod; you are to make it of gold, blue, purple, scarlet, and fine twisted linen.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is to be square when doubled, nine inches long and nine inches wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to set in it a setting for stones, four rows of stones, a row with a ruby, a topaz, and a beryl—the first row;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the second row, a turquoise, a sapphire, and an emerald;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the third row, a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the fourth row, a chrysolite, an onyx, and a jasper. They are to be enclosed in gold in their filigree settings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stones are to be for the names of the sons of Israel, twelve, according to the number of their names. Each name according to the twelve tribes is to be like the engravings of a seal.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make for the breastpiece braided chains like cords of pure gold,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you are to make for the breastpiece two gold rings and attach the two rings to the upper two ends of the breastpiece.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to attach the two gold chains to the two rings at the ends of the breastpiece;
speaker: Narrator

text: the other two ends of the two chains you will attach to the two settings and then attach them to the shoulder pieces of the ephod at the front of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make two rings of gold and put them on the other two ends of the breastpiece, on its edge that is on the inner side of the ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make two more gold rings and attach them to the bottom of the two shoulder pieces on the front of the ephod, close to the juncture above the waistband of the ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to tie the breastpiece by its rings to the rings of the ephod by blue cord, so that it may be above the waistband of the ephod, and so that the breastpiece will not be loose from the ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron will bear the names of the sons of Israel in the breastpiece of decision over his heart when he goes into the Holy Place, for a memorial before the Lord continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to put the Urim and the Thummim into the breastpiece of decision; and they are to be over Aaron’s heart when he goes in before the Lord. Aaron is to bear the decisions of the Israelites over his heart before the Lord continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make the robe of the ephod completely blue.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is to be an opening in its top in the center of it, with an edge all around the opening, the work of a weaver, like the opening of a collar, so that it cannot be torn.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet all around its hem and bells of gold between them all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pattern is to be a gold bell and a pomegranate, a gold bell and a pomegranate, all around the hem of the robe.
speaker: Narrator

text: The robe is to be on Aaron as he ministers, and his sound will be heard when he enters the Holy Place before the Lord and when he leaves, so that he does not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it the way a seal is engraved: ‘Holiness to the Lord.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to attach to it a blue cord so that it will be on the turban; it is to be on the front of the turban.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be on Aaron’s forehead, and Aaron will bear the iniquity of the holy things, which the Israelites are to sanctify by all their holy gifts; it will always be on his forehead, for their acceptance before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to weave the tunic of fine linen and make the turban of fine linen, and make the sash the work of an embroiderer.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For Aaron’s sons you are to make tunics, sashes, and headbands for glory and for beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to clothe them—your brother Aaron and his sons with him—and anoint them and ordain them and set them apart as holy, so that they may minister as my priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make for them linen undergarments to cover their naked bodies; they must cover from the waist to the thighs.
speaker: Narrator

text: These must be on Aaron and his sons when they enter the tent of meeting, or when they approach the altar to minister in the Holy Place, so that they bear no iniquity and die. It is to be a perpetual ordinance for him and for his descendants after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now this is what you are to do for them to consecrate them so that they may minister as my priests. Take a young bull and two rams without blemish;
speaker: Narrator

text: and bread made without yeast, and perforated cakes without yeast mixed with oil, and wafers without yeast spread with oil—you are to make them using fine wheat flour.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put them in one basket and present them in the basket, along with the bull and the two rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to present Aaron and his sons at the entrance of the tent of meeting. You are to wash them with water
speaker: Narrator

text: and take the garments and clothe Aaron with the tunic, the robe of the ephod, the ephod, and the breastpiece; you are to fasten the ephod on him by using the skillfully woven waistband.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put the turban on his head and put the holy diadem on the turban.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to take the anointing oil and pour it on his head and anoint him.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to present his sons and clothe them with tunics
speaker: Narrator

text: and wrap the sashes around Aaron and his sons and put headbands on them, and so the ministry of priesthood will belong to them by a perpetual ordinance. Thus you are to consecrate Aaron and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to present the bull at the front of the tent of meeting, and Aaron and his sons are to put their hands on the head of the bull.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to kill the bull before the Lord at the entrance to the tent of meeting
speaker: Narrator

text: and take some of the blood of the bull and put it on the horns of the altar with your finger; all the rest of the blood you are to pour out at the base of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to take all the fat that covers the entrails, and the lobe that is above the liver, and the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, and burn them on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the meat of the bull, its skin, and its dung you are to burn up outside the camp. It is the purification offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to take one ram, and Aaron and his sons are to lay their hands on the ram’s head,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you are to kill the ram and take its blood and splash it all around on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you are to cut the ram into pieces and wash the entrails and its legs and put them on its pieces and on its head
speaker: Narrator

text: and burn the whole ram on the altar. It is a burnt offering to the Lord, a soothing aroma; it is an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to take the second ram, and Aaron and his sons are to lay their hands on the ram’s head,
speaker: Narrator

text: and you are to kill the ram and take some of its blood and put it on the tip of the right ear of Aaron, on the tip of the right ear of his sons, on the thumb of their right hand, and on the big toe of their right foot, and then splash the blood all around on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to take some of the blood that is on the altar and some of the anointing oil and sprinkle it on Aaron, on his garments, on his sons, and on his sons’ garments with him, so that he may be holy, he and his garments along with his sons and his sons’ garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to take from the ram the fat, the fat tail, the fat that covers the entrails, the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, and the right thigh—for it is the ram for consecration—
speaker: Narrator

text: and one round flat cake of bread, one perforated cake of oiled bread, and one wafer from the basket of bread made without yeast that is before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to put all these in Aaron’s hands and in his sons’ hands, and you are to wave them as a wave offering before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you are to take them from their hands and burn them on the altar for a burnt offering, for a soothing aroma before the Lord. It is an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to take the breast of the ram of Aaron’s consecration; you are to wave it as a wave offering before the Lord, and it is to be your share.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to sanctify the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the contribution, which were waved and lifted up as a contribution from the ram of consecration, from what belongs to Aaron and to his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is to belong to Aaron and to his sons from the Israelites, by a perpetual ordinance, for it is a contribution. It is to be a contribution from the Israelites from their peace offerings, their contribution to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The holy garments that belong to Aaron are to belong to his sons after him, so that they may be anointed in them and consecrated in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who succeeds him from his sons, when he first comes to the tent of meeting to minister in the Holy Place, is to wear them for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to take the ram of the consecration and cook its meat in a holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron and his sons are to eat the meat of the ram and the bread that was in the basket at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are to eat those things by which atonement was made to consecrate and to set them apart, but no one else may eat them, for they are holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any of the meat from the consecration offerings or any of the bread is left over until morning, then you are to burn up what is left over. It must not be eaten, because it is holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus you are to do for Aaron and for his sons according to all that I have commanded you; you are to consecrate them for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day you are to prepare a bull for a purification offering for atonement. You are to purify the altar by making atonement for it, and you are to anoint it to set it apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven days you are to make atonement for the altar and set it apart as holy. Then the altar will be most holy. Anything that touches the altar will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now this is what you are to prepare on the altar every day continually: two lambs a year old.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first lamb you are to prepare in the morning, and the second lamb you are to prepare around sundown.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the first lamb offer a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a fourth of a hin of oil from pressed olives, and a fourth of a hin of wine as a drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second lamb you are to offer around sundown; you are to prepare for it the same meal offering as for the morning and the same drink offering, for a soothing aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This will be a regular burnt offering throughout your generations at the entrance of the tent of meeting before the Lord, where I will meet with you to speak to you there.
speaker: Narrator

text: There I will meet with the Israelites, and it will be set apart as holy by my glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I will set apart as holy the tent of meeting and the altar, and I will set apart as holy Aaron and his sons that they may minister as priests to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will reside among the Israelites, and I will be their God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they will know that I am the Lord their God, who brought them out from the land of Egypt, so that I may reside among them. I am the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to make an altar for burning incense; you are to make it of acacia wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its length is to be 18 inches and its width 18 inches; it will be square. Its height is to be 36 inches, with its horns of one piece with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to overlay it with pure gold—its top, its four walls, and its horns—and make a surrounding border of gold for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make two gold rings for it under its border, on its two flanks; you are to make them on its two sides. The rings will be places for poles to carry it with.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to put it in front of the curtain that is before the ark of the testimony (before the atonement lid that is over the testimony), where I will meet you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron is to burn sweet incense on it morning by morning; when he attends to the lamps he is to burn incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Aaron sets up the lamps around sundown he is to burn incense on it; it is to be a regular incense offering before the Lord throughout your generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not offer strange incense on it, nor burnt offering, nor meal offering, and you must not pour out a drink offering on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron is to make atonement on its horns once in the year with some of the blood of the sin offering for atonement; once in the year he is to make atonement on it throughout your generations. It is most holy to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you take a census of the Israelites according to their number, then each man is to pay a ransom for his life to the Lord when you number them, so that there will be no plague among them when you number them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who crosses over to those who are numbered is to pay this: a half shekel according to the shekel of the sanctuary (a shekel weighs twenty gerahs). The half shekel is to be an offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who crosses over to those numbered, from twenty years old and up, is to pay an offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rich are not to pay more and the poor are not to pay less than the half shekel when giving the offering of the Lord, to make atonement for your lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to receive the atonement money from the Israelites and give it for the service of the tent of meeting. It will be a memorial for the Israelites before the Lord, to make atonement for your lives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are also to make a large bronze basin with a bronze stand for washing. You are to put it between the tent of meeting and the altar and put water in it,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Aaron and his sons must wash their hands and their feet from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they enter the tent of meeting, they must wash with water so that they do not die. Also, when they approach the altar to minister by burning incense as an offering made by fire to the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: they must wash their hands and their feet so that they do not die. And this will be a perpetual ordinance for them and for their descendants throughout their generations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take choice spices: 12½ pounds of free-flowing myrrh, half that—about 6¼ pounds—of sweet-smelling cinnamon, 6¼ pounds of sweet-smelling cane,
speaker: Narrator

text: and 12½ pounds of cassia, all weighed according to the sanctuary shekel, and four quarts of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to make this into a sacred anointing oil, a perfumed compound, the work of a perfumer. It will be sacred anointing oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: “With it you are to anoint the tent of meeting, the ark of the testimony,
speaker: Narrator

text: the table and all its utensils, the lampstand and its utensils, the altar of incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: the altar for the burnt offering and all its utensils, and the laver and its base.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you are to sanctify them, and they will be most holy; anything that touches them will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to anoint Aaron and his sons and sanctify them so that they may minister as my priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you are to tell the Israelites: ‘This is to be my sacred anointing oil throughout your generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must not be applied to people’s bodies, and you must not make any like it with the same recipe. It is holy, and it must be holy to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever makes perfume like it and whoever puts any of it on someone not a priest will be cut off from his people.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Take spices, gum resin, onycha, galbanum, and pure frankincense of equal amounts
speaker: Narrator

text: and make it into an incense, a perfume, the work of a perfumer. It is to be finely ground, and pure and sacred.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to beat some of it very fine and put some of it before the ark of the testimony in the tent of meeting where I will meet with you; it is to be most holy to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the incense that you are to make, you must not make for yourselves using the same recipe; it is to be most holy to you, belonging to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever makes anything like it, to use as perfume, will be cut off from his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “See, I have chosen Bezalel son of Uri, the son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I have filled him with the Spirit of God in skill, in understanding, in knowledge, and in all kinds of craftsmanship,
speaker: Narrator

text: to make artistic designs for work with gold, with silver, and with bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: and with cutting and setting stone, and with cutting wood, to work in all kinds of craftsmanship.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, I have also given him Oholiab son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, and I have given ability to all the specially skilled, that they may make everything I have commanded you:
speaker: Narrator

text: the tent of meeting, the ark of the testimony, the atonement lid that is on it, all the furnishings of the tent,
speaker: Narrator

text: the table with its utensils, the pure lampstand with all its utensils, the altar of incense,
speaker: Narrator

text: the altar for the burnt offering with all its utensils, the large basin with its base,
speaker: Narrator

text: the woven garments, the holy garments for Aaron the priest and the garments for his sons, to minister as priests,
speaker: Narrator

text: the anointing oil, and sweet incense for the Holy Place. They will make all these things just as I have commanded you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘Surely you must keep my Sabbaths, for it is a sign between me and you throughout your generations, that you may know that I am the Lord who sanctifies you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must keep the Sabbath, for it is holy for you. Everyone who defiles it must surely be put to death; indeed, if anyone does any work on it, then that person will be cut off from among his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six days work may be done, but on the seventh day is a Sabbath of complete rest, holy to the Lord; anyone who does work on the Sabbath day must surely be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites must keep the Sabbath by observing the Sabbath throughout their generations as a perpetual covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a sign between me and the Israelites forever; for in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth, and on the seventh day he rested and was refreshed.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave Moses two tablets of testimony when he had finished speaking with him on Mount Sinai, tablets of stone written by the finger of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people saw that Moses delayed in coming down from the mountain, they gathered around Aaron and said to him, “Get up, make us gods that will go before us. As for this fellow Moses, the man who brought us up from the land of Egypt, we do not know what has become of him!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron said to them, “Break off the gold earrings that are on the ears of your wives, your sons, and your daughters, and bring them to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people broke off the gold earrings that were on their ears and brought them to Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: He accepted the gold from them, fashioned it with an engraving tool, and made a molten calf. Then they said, “These are your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Aaron saw this, he built an altar before it, and Aaron made a proclamation and said, “Tomorrow will be a feast to the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got up early on the next day and offered up burnt offerings and brought peace offerings, and the people sat down to eat and drink, and they rose up to play.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses, “Go quickly, descend, because your people, whom you brought up from the land of Egypt, have acted corruptly.
speaker: Narrator

text: They have quickly turned aside from the way that I commanded them—they have made for themselves a molten calf and have bowed down to it and sacrificed to it and said, ‘These are your gods, O Israel, which brought you up from the land of Egypt.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “I have seen this people. Look what a stiff-necked people they are!
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, leave me alone so that my anger can burn against them and I can destroy them, and I will make from you a great nation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses sought the favor of the Lord his God and said, “O Lord, why does your anger burn against your people, whom you have brought out from the land of Egypt with great power and with a mighty hand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should the Egyptians say, ‘For evil he led them out to kill them in the mountains and to destroy them from the face of the earth’? Turn from your burning anger, and relent of this evil against your people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel your servants, to whom you swore by yourself and told them, ‘I will multiply your descendants like the stars of heaven, and all this land that I have spoken about I will give to your descendants, and they will inherit it forever.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord relented over the evil that he had said he would do to his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses turned and went down from the mountain with the two tablets of the testimony in his hands. The tablets were written on both sides—they were written on the front and on the back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the tablets were the work of God, and the writing was the writing of God, engraved on the tablets.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joshua heard the noise of the people as they shouted, he said to Moses, “It is the sound of war in the camp!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “It is not the sound of those who shout for victory, nor is it the sound of those who cry because they are overcome, but the sound of singing I hear.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he approached the camp and saw the calf and the dancing, Moses became extremely angry. He threw the tablets from his hands and broke them to pieces at the bottom of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the calf they had made and burned it in the fire, ground it to powder, poured it out on the water, and made the Israelites drink it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Aaron, “What did this people do to you, that you have brought on them so great a sin?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron said, “Do not let your anger burn hot, my lord; you know these people, that they tend to evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to me, ‘Make us gods that will go before us, for as for this fellow Moses, the man who brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So I said to them, ‘Whoever has gold, break it off.’ So they gave it to me, and I threw it into the fire, and this calf came out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses saw that the people were running wild, for Aaron had let them get completely out of control, causing derision from their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses stood at the entrance of the camp and said, “Whoever is for the Lord, come to me.” All the Levites gathered around him,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said to them, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, has said ‘Each man fasten his sword on his side, and go back and forth from entrance to entrance throughout the camp, and each one kill his brother, his friend, and his neighbor.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites did what Moses ordered, and that day about 3,000 men of the people died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “You have been consecrated today for the Lord, for each of you was against his son or against his brother, so he has given a blessing to you today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day Moses said to the people, “You have committed a very serious sin, but now I will go up to the Lord—perhaps I can make atonement on behalf of your sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses returned to the Lord and said, “Alas, this people has committed a very serious sin, and they have made for themselves gods of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now, if you will forgive their sin…, but if not, wipe me out from your book that you have written.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Whoever has sinned against me—that person I will wipe out of my book.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now go, lead the people to the place I have spoken to you about. See, my angel will go before you. But on the day that I punish, I will indeed punish them for their sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord sent a plague on the people because they had made the calf—the one Aaron made.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go up from here, you and the people whom you brought up out of the land of Egypt, to the land I promised on oath to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, saying, ‘I will give it to your descendants.’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send an angel before you, and I will drive out the Canaanite, the Amorite, the Hittite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go up to a land flowing with milk and honey. But I will not go up among you, for you are a stiff-necked people, and I might destroy you on the way.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people heard this troubling word they mourned; no one put on his ornaments.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had said to Moses, “Tell the Israelites, ‘You are a stiff-necked people. If I went up among you for a moment, I might destroy you. Now take off your ornaments that I may know what I should do to you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites stripped off their ornaments by Mount Horeb.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the tent and pitched it outside the camp, at a good distance from the camp, and he called it the tent of meeting. Anyone seeking the Lord would go out to the tent of meeting that was outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when Moses went out to the tent, all the people would get up and stand at the entrance to their tents and watch Moses until he entered the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whenever Moses entered the tent, the pillar of cloud would descend and stand at the entrance of the tent, and the Lord would speak with Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people would see the pillar of cloud standing at the entrance of the tent, all the people, each one at the entrance of his own tent, would rise and worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord would speak to Moses face to face, the way a person speaks to a friend. Then Moses would return to the camp, but his servant, Joshua son of Nun, a young man, did not leave the tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to the Lord, “See, you have been saying to me, ‘Bring this people up,’ but you have not let me know whom you will send with me. But you said, ‘I know you by name, and also you have found favor in my sight.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now if I have found favor in your sight, show me your way, that I may know you, that I may continue to find favor in your sight. And see that this nation is your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “My presence will go with you, and I will give you rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said to him, “If your presence does not go with us, do not take us up from here.
speaker: Narrator

text: For how will it be known then that I have found favor in your sight, I and your people? Is it not by your going with us, so that we will be distinguished, I and your people, from all the people who are on the face of the earth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “I will do this thing also that you have requested, for you have found favor in my sight, and I know you by name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses said, “Show me your glory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “I will make all my goodness pass before your face, and I will proclaim the Lord by name before you; I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious; I will show mercy to whom I will show mercy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he added, “You cannot see my face, for no one can see me and live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said, “Here is a place by me; you will station yourself on a rock.
speaker: Narrator

text: When my glory passes by, I will put you in a cleft in the rock and will cover you with my hand while I pass by.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I will take away my hand, and you will see my back, but my face must not be seen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Cut out two tablets of stone like the first, and I will write on the tablets the words that were on the first tablets, which you smashed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be prepared in the morning, and go up in the morning to Mount Sinai, and station yourself for me there on the top of the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one is to come up with you; do not let anyone be seen anywhere on the mountain; not even the flocks or the herds may graze in front of that mountain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses cut out two tablets of stone like the first; early in the morning he went up to Mount Sinai, just as the Lord had commanded him, and he took in his hand the two tablets of stone.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord descended in the cloud and stood with him there and proclaimed the Lord by name.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord passed by before him and proclaimed: “The Lord, the Lord, the compassionate and gracious God, slow to anger, and abounding in loyal love and faithfulness,
speaker: Narrator

text: keeping loyal love for thousands, forgiving iniquity and transgression and sin. But he by no means leaves the guilty unpunished, responding to the transgression of fathers by dealing with children and children’s children, to the third and fourth generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses quickly bowed to the ground and worshiped
speaker: Narrator

text: and said, “If now I have found favor in your sight, O Lord, let my Lord go among us, for we are a stiff-necked people; pardon our iniquity and our sin, and take us for your inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “See, I am going to make a covenant before all your people. I will do wonders such as have not been done in all the earth, nor in any nation. All the people among whom you live will see the work of the Lord, for it is a fearful thing that I am doing with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Obey what I am commanding you this day. I am going to drive out before you the Amorite, the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land where you are going, lest it become a snare among you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rather you must destroy their altars, smash their images, and cut down their Asherah poles.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you must not worship any other god, for the Lord, whose name is Jealous, is a jealous God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful not to make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land, for when they prostitute themselves to their gods and sacrifice to their gods, and someone invites you, you will eat from his sacrifice;
speaker: Narrator

text: and you then take his daughters for your sons, and when his daughters prostitute themselves to their gods, they will make your sons prostitute themselves to their gods as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not make yourselves molten gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread. For seven days you must eat bread made without yeast, as I commanded you; do this at the appointed time of the month Abib, for in the month Abib you came out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every firstborn of the womb belongs to me, even every firstborn of your cattle that is a male, whether ox or sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now the firstling of a donkey you may redeem with a lamb, but if you do not redeem it, then break its neck. You must redeem all the firstborn of your sons.
“No one will appear before me empty-handed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On six days you may labor, but on the seventh day you must rest; even at the time of plowing and of harvest you are to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must observe the Feast of Weeks—the firstfruits of the harvest of wheat—and the Feast of Ingathering at the end of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: At three times in the year all your men must appear before the Sovereign Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will drive out the nations before you and enlarge your borders; no one will covet your land when you go up to appear before the Lord your God three times in the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must not offer the blood of my sacrifice with yeast; the sacrifice from the Feast of Passover must not remain until the following morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The first of the firstfruits of your soil you must bring to the house of the Lord your God.
“You must not cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Write down these words, for in accordance with these words I have made a covenant with you and with Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he was there with the Lord forty days and forty nights; he did not eat bread, and he did not drink water. He wrote on the tablets the words of the covenant, the Ten Commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Moses came down from Mount Sinai with the two tablets of the testimony in his hand—when he came down from the mountain, Moses did not know that the skin of his face shone while he talked with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Aaron and all the Israelites saw Moses, the skin of his face shone, and they were afraid to approach him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses called to them, so Aaron and all the leaders of the community came back to him, and Moses spoke to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this all the Israelites approached, and he commanded them all that the Lord had spoken to him on Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses finished speaking with them, he would put a veil on his face.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Moses went in before the Lord to speak with him, he would remove the veil until he came out. Then he would come out and tell the Israelites what he had been commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites would see the face of Moses, that the skin of Moses’ face shone, Moses would put the veil on his face again, until he went in to speak with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses assembled the whole community of the Israelites and said to them, “These are the things that the Lord has commanded you to do.
speaker: Narrator
